Award.AwardTitle: Cosmic Fields: Inflation and Dark Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Marcelo Gleiser and Robert R. Caldwell at the Dartmouth College.

One of the most remarkable scientific discoveries of the last decades is that our universe has a history: it emerged from a hot and dense initial state some 13.7 billion years ago and has been expanding and cooling ever since. As is the case with archeologists, modern cosmologists seek clues left over in the present to study the past. In particular, cosmologists seek to uncover the fundamental laws that govern the origin of matter and the evolution of material structures -- from atoms to stars and galaxies -- in the universe. Current observational evidence indicates that the rate at which our universe expands has passed through two anomalous periods when its rate accelerated dramatically: one within the first moments of its existence, and another in current times. The proposed research focuses on both periods of anomalous ultrafast expansion. During the first period, known as cosmic inflation, a fundamental open question is how the universe transitioned from the ultrafast expansion to a more moderate expansion rate. The answer is implicitly related to the mechanism that caused this fast expansion. As it ended, matter was explosively created and complex material structures emerged. Models describing the emergence of these structures and their properties will be developed, and their impact on the cosmic history will be investigated. The second period of fast expansion is believed to have been fueled by the still unknown "dark energy." The research outlined here will attempt to elucidate the fundamental properties of dark energy using techniques from high-energy physics, linking fundamental theory to observational evidence.

This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professors Gleiser and Caldwell will involve graduate and undergraduate students in their research, and thereby provide critical training to junior physicists beginning research in this field. They also intend to give public lectures on their research results, and write articles and essays in the popular media about cosmology and some of its cutting-edge ideas. Both are active in the public understanding of science through their articles in magazines and newspapers, their appearances in TV documentaries, and also as a blogger for National Public Radio (Gleiser).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Perhaps the most fascinating question we can ask about the universe concerns its origin: how did the universe come into being? What physical processes dictated its early life? Separated by 14 billion years as we are from the beginning of time, it’s hard to think that scientists can actually make progress concerning such questions. Yet, this is precisely the goal of modern cosmology and of this research project.

For the past three years, we have investigated two epochs of great importance in the cosmic history. Both are characterized by a fast — exponentially fast — expansion of space. One of the them—the epoch known as inflation—was suggested to explain many questions left open by the conventional Big Bang model; the other—the one called dark energy—came as a surprise in 1998, when it was discovered by two teams of astronomers.

It’s important to point out what we mean by expanding space: the very geometry of space stretches like a rubber sheet, a consequence of Einstein’s theory of general relativity. 

If these two epochs of fast expansion did happen, one very early one and another still ongoing, we need to understand the details: What caused them? What are their consequences? Can they help us figure out unknown properties of the universe and of its material components?

 In one part of the project, we investigated how would such primordial fast expansion end. This study made use of a large-scale computer simulation, where we essentially recreated a simplified replica of the expanding early universe. This simulation is our “lab” so to speak, where we could address some of the key questions in a controlled way. Are there any remnants from the fast expansion that can tell us what happened and how it ended? We found that many theories that describe how the particles of matter may have interacted in these early times predict that such remnants do indeed tend to form and that they survive for a very long time. In particular, one key question we asked was whether other particles could destroy these remnants, by stealing their energy away. We found that the remants (called "oscillons") are quite robust, able to survive such attempts.

In another part of the project, we investigated how modifying the theory of gravity can impact the cosmic history: What are the observational consequences of changing Einstein’s theories? Could a different theory of gravity explain some of the current mysteries, for example, dark energy, the second fast expansion? Perhaps dark energy is an effect from our priviledged place in the universe? It was found that such models contradict known observational results. We don't occupy a special place in the cosmos.  On the other hand, adding a novel kind of electromagnetic force to the matter and radiation content of the universe has interesting observational consequences, such as the generation of a large-scale (trans-galactic) magnetic field that has properties that depend on the field responsible for the inflationanry epoch. We don't know if such theories are correct, but they do have testable consequences.

Our work allowed us to constrain possible deviations from conventional gravity, as well as to show how rich the early dynamics of the universe can be. We expect to continue investigating the physics of the early universe, so as to help uncover some of the great mysteries of modern science.
